description: CRITICAL: Priority Overlap between 'High' and 'Medium' rules regarding study phases and data types.
WARNING: 'Low' priority rule is too broad and may capture abstracts that should be classified as Medium or High if not processed strictly in order.
WARNING: Keyword specificity risk. Some CLIENT KEYWORDS (e.g., 'Phosphate binder', 'Phosphate') are generic and may cause false positives if not paired with context.

original_text: Phase 2 data, Phase 3 data (including meta-analyses), real-world data (including PROs and registry data), Phosphate binders/phosphate lowering treatment
suggested_text: Phase 2 data, Phase 3 data (including meta-analyses), real-world data (including PROs and registry data), Phosphate binders/phosphate lowering treatment (excluding studies only describing trial design, endpoints, or preclinical data without results)
rationale: Clarifies that High Priority is reserved for studies with substantive results, not just design or endpoints, reducing overlap with Medium.

original_text: Phase 1 data, retrospective analyses, prognostic studies, trial designs, preclinical studies; studies with trial outcomes and endpoints; other general studies
suggested_text: Phase 1 data, retrospective analyses, prognostic studies, trial designs, preclinical studies; studies with trial outcomes and endpoints (excluding Phase 2/3, real-world data, and phosphate binder treatments as defined in High Priority); other general studies
rationale: Explicitly excludes High Priority criteria to enforce mutual exclusivity.

original_text: All abstracts that only have mention of an indication and does not include any other data
suggested_text: All abstracts that only mention an indication and do not include any study data, outcomes, endpoints, or treatments as defined in higher priorities
rationale: Prevents Low Priority from capturing abstracts that should be classified as Medium or High.

original_text: All abstracts that have client provided keywords
suggested_text: All abstracts that have client provided keywords (ensure keywords are matched in relevant clinical or scientific context to avoid false positives)
rationale: Improves keyword accuracy and reduces risk of irrelevant matches.
